exercises.instructions: Anchor a resistance band at waist height. Stand with the affected arm's elbow bent 90 degrees and tucked to your side, holding the band. Slowly pull the band outwards, rotating your forearm away from your body. Control the movement back to the start. Keep your elbow stable.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1-2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing with a resistance band anchored to a door, performing external rotation with elbow bent 90 degrees and tucked to the side.

exercises.name: Scaption (Shoulder Blade Elevation in Scapular Plane)
exercises.instructions: Stand with arms at your sides, thumbs pointing up. Slowly raise both arms up to shoulder height and slightly forward (about 30 degrees from the front, in the plane of the scapula), forming a 'V' shape. Control the movement back down. Avoid shrugging.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1 time daily. Use light weights (1-3 lbs) when tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing, raising arms to shoulder height at a 30-degree angle from the front, with thumbs pointing up, demonstrating the scaption movement.

exercises.name: Wall Slides / Overhead Reach
exercises.instructions: Stand facing a wall, about a foot away. Place your forearms on the wall, elbows bent. Slowly slide your arms up the wall, raising them overhead, keeping forearms and hands in contact with the wall. Move only to a pain-free range. Control the descent.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1 time daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing facing a wall, forearms on the wall, sliding hands and forearms up the wall into an overhead reach position.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening & Return to Function Phase
phase_3.goal: Achieve full pain-free range of motion, maximum strength, power, and endurance of the shoulder complex. Incorporate functional and sport-specific activities, and prevent recurrence.

exercises.name: Overhead Press (Dumbbell)
exercises.instructions: Sit or stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing forward. Press the dumbbells directly overhead in a controlled manner, avoiding excessive arching of the back. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the start position.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-12 repetitions, progressing weight as tolerated, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient sitting or standing, performing an overhead press with dumbbells, showing good form and controlled movement.

exercises.name: Push-ups (Wall, Incline, or Floor)
exercises.instructions: Start with wall push-ups, then progress to incline (hands on a bench/chair), and finally floor push-ups. Maintain a straight body line from head to heels. Lower your chest towards the surface by bending elbows, then push back up. Focus on scapular stability.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-15 repetitions, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing an incline push-up with hands on a stable bench, demonstrating a straight body and controlled movement.

exercises.name: Plyometric Ball Throws (if applicable for sport)
exercises.instructions: Stand facing a wall, holding a light medicine ball. Throw the ball against the wall using an overhead motion (similar to a sport-specific throw), catching it on the rebound. Focus on power and controlled deceleration.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 throws, 2 times per week (ensure adequate warm-up and cool-down).
exercises.image_description: Athlete throwing a medicine ball overhead against a wall, demonstrating a dynamic and powerful shoulder movement.

exercises.name: Eccentric Rotator Cuff Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Using a resistance band or light dumbbell, perform the concentric (lifting) phase of an exercise (e.g., external rotation) with both hands, then slowly control the eccentric (lowering) phase with only the affected arm. Emphasize slow, controlled lowering over 3-5 seconds.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-12 repetitions, 2 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient using both hands to lift a light dumbbell into an external rotation position, then slowly lowering it with only the affected arm for eccentric control.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis typically involves a comprehensive patient history (onset, aggravating/relieving factors, mechanism of injury), physical examination including observation for muscle atrophy/postural abnormalities, palpation for tenderness over rotator cuff tendons, active/passive range of motion assessment, and specific orthopedic special tests (e.g., Neer's impingement, Hawkins-Kennedy, Empty Can test for supraspinatus weakness, Speed's test for biceps tendinitis often co-occurring). Manual muscle testing (MMT) of rotator cuff and deltoid, and evaluation of scapular dyskinesis are crucial. Imaging such as MRI may confirm tendon inflammation or tears.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy:
Manual therapy techniques may include: 
1. Soft tissue mobilization/massage to the rotator cuff muscles, deltoid, pectoralis major/minor, latissimus dorsi, upper trapezius, and subscapularis to reduce muscle guarding and improve tissue extensibility. 
2. Myofascial release techniques to address fascial restrictions. 
3. Grade I-IV joint mobilizations for the glenohumeral joint (e.g., posterior, inferior glides to improve impingement space and ROM), acromioclavicular (AC) joint, sternoclavicular (SC) joint, and scapulothoracic articulation to restore optimal joint mechanics and reduce pain. 
4. Neuromuscular re-education to improve scapular control and proprioception.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid pain-provoking movements, especially overhead activities and heavy lifting, particularly in the acute phase. Ensure proper warm-up and cool-down for all exercises. Educate the patient on proper posture and ergonomic modifications for daily activities and work. Avoid sudden, ballistic movements. Progress exercises gradually, respecting pain and tissue healing. Discontinue any exercise that causes sharp or increasing pain. Monitor for signs of worsening inflammation or progression to a full tear.
clinical_notes.scientific_reference: Kibler, W. B., Sciascia, A. D., & Uhl, T. L. (2012). Clinical practice guidelines for shoulder rehabilitation. Journal of Athletic Training, 47(4), 433-447. (General reference for comprehensive shoulder rehab principles)

clinical_presentation.definition: Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome (PFPS), often referred to as 'runner's knee' or 'anterior knee pain,' is characterized by diffuse pain originating from the retropatellar or peripatellar region of the knee. The pain is typically aggravated by activities that load the patellofemoral joint, such as ascending/descending stairs, running, squatting, prolonged sitting with flexed knees ('theater sign'), and jumping. It is considered a multifactorial condition involving impairments in lower extremity biomechanics, muscle strength and activation, and local patellofemoral joint mechanics.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A person, possibly an athlete or a young adult, with their hand gently touching the front of their knee, indicating pain in the patellofemoral region. The image should convey discomfort, perhaps during an activity like walking down stairs or after prolonged sitting. A focus on the knee joint area with subtle signs of inflammation or tenderness could be included.

electrotherapy.parameters: High-frequency (50-100 Hz), short pulse duration (50-100 µs), sensory level intensity (strong but comfortable tingling), continuous mode. Duration: 20-30 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes proximal and distal to the patella, or encompassing the area of maximal pain. Can be placed longitudinally over the quadriceps if diffuse pain is present.
electrotherapy.goal: Pain modulation and symptomatic relief during the acute and subacute phases, allowing for increased tolerance to exercise.
electrotherapy.image_description: A close-up view of a knee with two or four TENS electrodes placed around the patella, connected by wires to a TENS unit.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 30-50 Hz (tetanic contraction), Pulse Duration: 200-400 µs. On/Off Ratio: 1:3 to 1:5 (e.g., 10 seconds on, 30-50 seconds off). Ramp: 2 seconds. Intensity: As high as tolerated to achieve strong quadriceps contraction. Repetitions: 10-15 contractions. Duration: 15-20 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes over the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) and a common motor point of the quadriceps (e.g., rectus femoris or vastus lateralis). Ensure good contact over muscle belly.
electrotherapy.goal: Facilitate quadriceps activation, particularly VMO, to improve patellar tracking and overall knee stability. Useful for individuals with quadriceps inhibition post-injury or surgery, or significant strength deficits.
electrotherapy.image_description: A close-up view of the anterior thigh above the knee, showing two NMES electrodes placed over the VMO and one of the other quadriceps heads (e.g., rectus femoris), with wires attached.

phase_1.name: Pain Control & Initial Activation (Weeks 0-2)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, re-establish basic quadriceps and hip muscle activation, maintain range of motion, and educate on activity modification.

exercises.name: Quadriceps Sets
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your leg extended. Press the back of your knee into the surface, tightening your thigh muscles. Hold for 5-10 seconds, focusing on feeling the muscle contract. Ensure the patella moves superiorly.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine with one leg extended, knee slightly pressed down, indicating quadriceps contraction. A hand might be palpating the quadriceps muscle.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raises (SLR) - Supine
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with one knee bent and the foot flat on the floor. Keep the other leg straight, tighten your quadriceps, and lift the straight leg slowly about 6-12 inches off the floor. Keep the knee locked and leg straight throughout. Lower slowly. Avoid arching your back.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine with one leg bent, the other leg extended and lifted a few inches off the floor, demonstrating a straight leg raise.

exercises.name: Gluteal Bridge
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Engage your glutes and lift your hips off the floor until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. Hold briefly, then slowly lower. Avoid arching the lower back excessively.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine with knees bent, hips lifted off the floor in a bridge position.

exercises.name: Patellar Mobilizations (Self-Mobilization)
exercises.instructions: Sit with your knee relaxed and extended. Gently grasp the patella with your thumb and index finger. Gently glide the patella medially, laterally, superiorly, and inferiorly for 30 seconds in each direction. Focus on gentle, pain-free movement.
exercises.dosage: Perform 3-5 minutes, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A hand gently moving the patella on an extended knee, demonstrating medial and lateral patellar glides.

phase_2.name: Progressive Strengthening & Neuromuscular Re-education (Weeks 2-6)
phase_2.goal: Improve quadriceps and hip strength (especially abductors and external rotators), enhance neuromuscular control, progress weight-bearing activities, and gradually increase activity tolerance.

exercises.name: Mini Squats (Wall Slides)
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, feet shoulder-width apart, about 6-12 inches from the wall. Slowly slide down the wall, bending your knees to a maximum of 30-45 degrees (pain-free range). Keep your back flat against the wall. Hold briefly, then slide back up. Focus on smooth, controlled movement.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Person standing with their back against a wall, knees slightly bent in a mini-squat position, sliding down.

exercises.name: Clamshells (Side-Lying Hip Abduction with External Rotation)
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side with knees bent at 90 degrees and hips slightly flexed. Keep your feet together. Keeping your top hip stacked directly over the bottom hip, lift your top knee towards the ceiling, rotating at the hip. Do not let your pelvis roll backward. Slowly lower. Can add a resistance band above knees.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 15-20 repetitions per side, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying on their side with knees bent, lifting the top knee upwards while keeping feet together, demonstrating a clamshell exercise.

exercises.name: Step-Ups (Low Box)
exercises.instructions: Stand in front of a low step (4-6 inches high). Place one foot entirely on the step. Push through the heel of your stepping foot to step up, bringing the other foot to meet it or just tapping it. Slowly lower the non-stepping leg back to the floor with control. Focus on maintaining knee alignment (avoiding valgus collapse).
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions per leg, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Person stepping onto a low box, demonstrating proper form for a step-up, focusing on knee alignment.

exercises.name: Single Leg Stance / Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, maintaining good posture. Hold for 30-60 seconds. Progress by closing eyes, standing on an unstable surface (e.g., foam pad), or performing head turns.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 repetitions per leg, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Person standing on one leg with the other leg slightly lifted, demonstrating good balance and posture.

phase_3.name: Functional Integration & Return to Activity (Weeks 6-12+)
phase_3.goal: Restore full strength, power, and endurance; integrate multi-planar and sport-specific movements; optimize neuromuscular control during dynamic activities; and prepare for return to desired activities/sport while minimizing recurrence risk.

exercises.name: Lunges (Forward and Lateral)
exercises.instructions: Forward Lunge: Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at approximately 90 degrees. Ensure the front knee stays behind the toes and the back knee hovers above the ground. Push back to starting position. Lateral Lunge: Step to the side, keeping the trailing leg straight and bending the leading knee, sending hips back. Focus on controlled movement and knee alignment.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-12 repetitions per leg, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a forward lunge, showing correct knee and body alignment.

exercises.name: Box Jumps (Low Height)
exercises.instructions: Stand in front of a low, stable box (6-12 inches). Squat down slightly and powerfully jump onto the box, landing softly with both feet. Step down slowly. Focus on a soft, controlled landing and proper knee alignment. Progress gradually.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 5-8 repetitions, 2-3 times per week (if appropriate for patient's goals and pain levels).
exercises.image_description: Person jumping onto a low box, captured mid-air or just at landing, demonstrating controlled movement.

exercises.name: Agility Drills (Cone Drills)
exercises.instructions: Set up cones in various patterns (e.g., shuttle run, T-drill). Perform short, quick bursts of running, changing direction, and stopping. Focus on controlled acceleration and deceleration, maintaining knee alignment during pivots.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 sets of 2-3 minutes of continuous drills, 2-3 times per week, with adequate rest between sets.
exercises.image_description: Person performing an agility drill around cones, showing dynamic movement and change of direction.

exercises.name: Single Leg Hop & Hold
exercises.instructions: Hop forward a short distance on one leg and immediately stick the landing, holding the balanced position for 3-5 seconds. Ensure the knee tracks over the toes and hip is stable. Progress to hopping in different directions (lateral, diagonal).
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-10 hops per leg, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Person landing from a single-leg hop, holding the balanced position with good knee and hip alignment.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A comprehensive assessment is crucial for PFPS. This includes detailed history, palpation (patellar facets, retinacula), special tests (Clarke's sign, active patellar grind test), gait analysis, assessment of lower extremity alignment (Q-angle, foot posture), flexibility (quadriceps, hamstrings, ITB, hip flexors, gastroc/soleus), and strength testing (quadriceps, gluteal muscles - medius/maximus, hip external rotators, core). Dynamic movement analysis (e.g., single-leg squat, step-down test) is vital to identify movement impairments such as dynamic knee valgus. Differential diagnosis should rule out other knee pathologies.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques may include: Patellar mobilizations (medial/lateral glides, tilts, rotations) to improve patellar mobility and reduce symptoms. Soft tissue mobilization/release for quadriceps, iliotibial band (ITB), hip flexors, and calf muscles to address tightness and reduce compensatory muscle activity. Joint mobilizations for the tibiofemoral joint or hip joint if specific hypomobilities are identified. Neural mobilization (e.g., femoral nerve glides) if neural tissue involvement is suspected. Dry needling may be considered for myofascial trigger points in the quadriceps, gluteal muscles, or hip musculature.
clinical_notes.precautions: Always ensure exercises are performed in a pain-free range. Gradual progression of load, intensity, and duration is paramount. Avoid activities that exacerbate pain significantly. Monitor for increased swelling or persistent pain. Proper form and biomechanics must be emphasized throughout all exercises. Patient education regarding activity modification, proper footwear, and ergonomic considerations (e.g., prolonged sitting posture) is essential. Compliance with home exercise program and adherence to gradual return-to-sport guidelines are critical for successful outcomes and prevention of recurrence.
clinical_notes.scientific_reference: Powers, C. M. (2010). The influence of altered lower-extremity kinematics on patellofemoral pain syndrome. Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy, 40(2), 42-51. Retrieved from multiple peer-reviewed sources and clinical guidelines for Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome rehabilitation.

clinical_presentation.definition: Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) is an acute, rapidly progressive, acquired inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy affecting the peripheral nervous system. It is characterized by an autoimmune response often triggered by an infection, leading to demyelination and axonal damage of peripheral nerves. This typically results in ascending flaccid paralysis, which can range from mild weakness to complete paralysis, often involving respiratory muscles and potentially requiring mechanical ventilation. Sensory disturbances (paresthesia, numbness) and absent or diminished deep tendon reflexes are common. The course involves a progressive phase (days to weeks), a plateau phase, and a recovery phase (weeks to years).
clinical_presentation.image_description: Stock photo of a person in a hospital bed with a physical therapist gently assisting with passive range of motion of the legs and arms, with medical equipment in the background, emphasizing muscle weakness and the early stages of recovery from a neurological condition.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 35-50 Hz; Pulse Width: 200-300 microseconds; On/Off Ratio: 1:3 to 1:5 (e.g., 5-10 seconds on, 15-50 seconds off) to prevent fatigue; Ramp Up/Down: 1-2 seconds. Intensity: To achieve a strong, but comfortable, muscle contraction without over-fatiguing the patient.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes should be placed over the motor points or belly of the weakened muscles (e.g., quadriceps, tibialis anterior, gastrocnemius, deltoid, wrist extensors). Ensure good skin contact and avoid bony prominences. Monitor skin for irritation.
electrotherapy.goal: Prevent disuse atrophy, maintain muscle viability, facilitate muscle re-education and recruitment, improve motor control, and assist in strengthening as voluntary contraction returns.
electrotherapy.image_description: Close-up of a physical therapist applying two surface electrodes to the belly of the quadriceps muscle on a patient's thigh, connected to a portable NMES device with visible wires.

phase_1.name: Acute & Early Recovery Phase
phase_1.goal: Maintain joint mobility, prevent contractures, prevent skin breakdown, maintain respiratory function, preserve muscle viability, provide gentle sensory input, and prevent complications of immobility.

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion (PROM) Exercises
exercises.instructions: The therapist or caregiver passively moves all major joints (shoulders, elbows, wrists, fingers, hips, knees, ankles, toes) through their full pain-free range. Perform slowly and rhythmically.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions per joint, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Physical therapist gently performing passive knee flexion and extension on a patient lying supine in a hospital bed.

exercises.name: Positioning and Splinting
exercises.instructions: Regularly change patient's position (every 2 hours) to prevent pressure sores. Use pillows, wedges, and foam supports. Apply static splints (e.g., resting hand splints, ankle-foot orthoses) to prevent contractures like foot drop or wrist drop.
exercises.dosage: Continuous or intermittent splinting as needed, repositioning every 2 hours.
exercises.image_description: Patient's foot supported by a soft ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) while lying in bed, with pillows positioned to prevent external rotation.

exercises.name: Gentle Active-Assisted Range of Motion (AAROM)
exercises.instructions: Once minimal muscle activation is detected (MRC grade 1-2), assist the patient in moving their limbs through available range. Encourage patient effort within their capabilities, avoiding over-fatigue.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions per joint, 1-2 times per day, progressing as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Physical therapist guiding a patient's arm through shoulder flexion, with the patient assisting slightly, in a supine position.

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Place a hand on the abdomen and focus on breathing deeply, feeling the abdomen rise and fall. Encourage slow, controlled inhalations and exhalations to maximize lung capacity.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 deep breaths, 3-5 times per day, or as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine with one hand on their chest and the other on their abdomen, demonstrating diaphragmatic breathing.

phase_2.name: Subacute & Intermediate Recovery Phase
phase_2.goal: Progressively increase muscle strength and endurance, improve motor control, develop trunk stability, initiate sitting and standing balance, and prepare for functional mobility.

exercises.name: Active Range of Motion (AROM) and Gravity-Eliminated Exercises
exercises.instructions: Encourage active movement of all joints against gravity when strength is MRC grade 3. For muscles with MRC grade 2, perform movements in gravity-eliminated positions (e.g., knee flexion/extension while lying on a smooth surface).
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient actively performing knee extension while sitting on the edge of a bed, demonstrating overcoming gravity.

exercises.name: Progressive Resistive Exercises (PREs)
exercises.instructions: Once muscles reach MRC grade 3+, introduce light resistance using body weight, gravity, resistance bands, or light weights. Start with minimal resistance and gradually increase as strength improves, avoiding over-fatigue. Focus on key functional muscle groups.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 3-4 times per week, with rest days.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing bicep curls with a light dumbbell, seated on a treatment table.

exercises.name: Mat Exercises (Core and Trunk Stability)
exercises.instructions: Bridging, trunk rotation (supine), quadruped rocking, modified planks (on knees). Focus on engaging core muscles to improve trunk control for sitting and standing.
exercises.dosage: 8-15 repetitions or 30-60 second holds, 2-3 sets, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing a bridge exercise on a mat, lifting hips off the floor.

exercises.name: Sitting Balance Training
exercises.instructions: Static sitting on a firm surface, then progress to dynamic sitting activities (reaching, weight shifting, perturbation training) with therapist guarding.
exercises.dosage: 15-30 minutes, 1-2 times per day, with breaks as needed.
exercises.image_description: Physical therapist guarding a patient seated on the edge of a bed, encouraging them to reach for objects.

exercises.name: Pre-Gait and Standing Balance Training
exercises.instructions: Standing in parallel bars (static standing, weight shifting), mini-squats, marching in place. Progress to single leg stance support with therapist.
exercises.dosage: 10-20 minutes, 1-2 times per day, as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing in parallel bars with a physical therapist assisting, practicing weight shifts side-to-side.

phase_3.name: Advanced Recovery & Reintegration Phase
phase_3.goal: Maximize functional independence, improve cardiovascular endurance, agility, coordination, and facilitate return to pre-morbid activities (work, leisure, sport).

exercises.name: Advanced Progressive Resistive Exercises
exercises.instructions: Continue with progressive resistance training using weights, machines, and resistance bands to further increase strength and power in all major muscle groups. Incorporate compound movements.
exercises.dosage: 8-15 repetitions, 2-4 sets, 3-5 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing leg presses on a gym machine, demonstrating moderate resistance.

exercises.name: Advanced Balance and Proprioception Training
exercises.instructions: Tandem stance, single leg stance (eyes open/closed), balance board/foam, dynamic balance activities (walking heel-to-toe, obstacle courses, reaching during gait).
exercises.dosage: 15-30 minutes, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing on a BOSU ball, maintaining balance with arms outstretched.

exercises.name: Gait and Ambulation Training
exercises.instructions: Walking on varied surfaces (uneven ground, carpet, ramps), stair climbing, community ambulation, increasing speed and distance. Incorporate dual-task activities during gait.
exercises.dosage: 20-60 minutes walking, 3-5 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient walking independently on a paved outdoor path, looking confident.

exercises.name: Cardiovascular Endurance Training
exercises.instructions: Stationary cycling, elliptical, swimming, treadmill walking/jogging (if appropriate). Gradually increase duration and intensity.
exercises.dosage: 20-40 minutes, 3-5 times per week, at a moderate intensity (RPE 11-14).
exercises.image_description: Patient riding a stationary bicycle in a physical therapy gym.

exercises.name: Task-Specific Functional Training
exercises.instructions: Rehearsal of specific activities of daily living (ADLs) and instrumental ADLs (IADLs) that are challenging for the patient (e.g., dressing, cooking, cleaning, lifting objects, driving simulations).
exercises.dosage: Integrate throughout the day, practicing specific tasks as needed.
exercises.image_description: Patient practicing reaching for objects on a kitchen shelf, simulating daily tasks.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis of GBS is typically made clinically based on rapidly progressive weakness, absent/diminished reflexes, and often supported by electrodiagnostic studies (nerve conduction studies showing demyelination or axonal damage) and CSF analysis (elevated protein with normal cell count). Physical therapy assessment focuses on detailed neurological examination (muscle strength using MRC scale, sensation, reflexes), functional status (FIM, Barthel Index), balance, gait, range of motion, respiratory function, pain assessment, and assessment for potential complications (e.g., foot drop, pressure sores). Baseline measurements are crucial for tracking recovery.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques may be used cautiously. Gentle passive range of motion and joint mobilizations can help maintain joint integrity and prevent stiffness, particularly in joints prone to contractures (ankles, wrists). Soft tissue mobilization may be used for pain relief, muscle spasm, or to address secondary musculoskeletal issues arising from altered movement patterns. Neural mobilizations might be considered in later stages as tolerated, but careful monitoring for exacerbation of symptoms is essential.
clinical_notes.precautions: Vigilant monitoring for over-fatigue is paramount, as patients with GBS are highly susceptible to post-exertional fatigue, which can delay recovery. Activity must be carefully graded and symptom-limited. Monitor respiratory status closely, especially in acute phases. Protect skin integrity to prevent pressure sores. Watch for signs of autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias, blood pressure fluctuations). Pain management is crucial. Avoid overstretching denervated muscles. Educate patients and caregivers on energy conservation techniques and pacing activities.

scientific_reference: O'Sullivan, S. B., Schmitz, T. J., & Fulk, G. D. (2019). Physical Rehabilitation. F.A. Davis Company.

clinical_presentation.definition: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic autoimmune disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis, primarily affecting the small joints of the hands and feet, but can also involve larger joints like knees, shoulders, and hips. It leads to inflammation of the synovial membrane, causing pain, swelling, stiffness, and progressive joint destruction, cartilage erosion, and bone deformity. Systemic symptoms like fatigue, malaise, and fever are common.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Close-up of a person's hands showing typical signs of Rheumatoid Arthritis, including swollen, red, and deformed metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, ulnar deviation of fingers, and Boutonnière or Swan-neck deformities. The skin might appear thin or atrophic.

electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional TENS: Frequency 80-120 Hz, Pulse Duration 50-100 µs, Intensity to comfortable sensation (strong but not painful), duration 30-60 minutes, 1-3 times daily as needed for pain.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the painful joint or over nerve pathways supplying the painful area. Ensure good skin contact.
electrotherapy.goal: To provide symptomatic pain relief by stimulating sensory nerves and activating endogenous opioid mechanisms (gate control theory and opioid release).
electrotherapy.image_description: Illustration showing TENS electrodes placed on the dorsal aspect of a swollen wrist joint, with wires connecting to a small portable TENS unit.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency 1 or 3 MHz (depending on joint depth), Pulsed mode (e.g., 1:3 or 1:4 duty cycle), Intensity 0.5-1.0 W/cm², Duration 5-10 minutes per joint, 3-5 times per week during periods of active inflammation.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply coupling gel generously over the affected joint and surrounding soft tissues. Move the ultrasound head in slow, overlapping circles or longitudinal strokes over the area.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce inflammation, promote soft tissue healing, and alleviate pain in acutely or subacutely inflamed joints through non-thermal mechanical effects.
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a physical therapist applying an ultrasound transducer with gel over a patient's knee joint, with the ultrasound machine visible in the background.

phase_1.name: Acute / Inflammatory Phase - Joint Protection & Pain Management
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, preserve joint integrity, maintain existing range of motion, and educate on joint protection principles.

exercises.name: Gentle Active Assisted Range of Motion (AAROM) / Passive Range of Motion (PROM)
exercises.instructions: Gently move each affected joint through its available range of motion without pain. Use your other hand or a stick/towel to assist. Avoid end-range stretching. Perform slow, controlled movements.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions per joint, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A patient gently moving their fingers and wrist through range of motion, possibly with the aid of their other hand to support the movement. Emphasize a relaxed, non-strained expression.

exercises.name: Isometric Muscle Contractions
exercises.instructions: Gently contract muscles around affected joints without causing joint movement. Hold the contraction for a few seconds. For example, gently push palms together for hand muscles, or perform quadriceps sets by tightening thigh muscles.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 3-5 seconds, 5-8 repetitions, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A person sitting with a rolled towel under their knee, gently pressing the knee down to activate the quadriceps muscles without moving the joint, or pressing palms together.

exercises.name: Tendon Gliding Exercises (for Hands)
exercises.instructions: Perform a series of hand positions: 1) Straight hand, 2) Hook fist (MCPs flexed, IPs straight), 3) Full fist (all joints flexed), 4) Tabletop (MCPs straight, IPs flexed), 5) Straight fist (MCPs flexed, PIPs flexed, DIPs straight). Move slowly and gently.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions of the sequence, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A sequence of five hand positions demonstrating tendon gliding exercises, from a fully open hand to a full fist.

phase_2.name: Sub-acute / Rehabilitation Phase - Strength & Functional Mobility
phase_2.goal: To improve muscle strength, endurance, joint stability, flexibility, and functional capacity while continuing joint protection.

exercises.name: Light Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Using a light resistance band, perform exercises like shoulder flexion/abduction, elbow flexion/extension, knee flexion/extension. Ensure movements are controlled and do not cause pain. Start with low resistance.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A person performing a bicep curl with a light resistance band, demonstrating good form and controlled movement, possibly seated.

exercises.name: Therapeutic Cycling / Aquatic Exercises
exercises.instructions: Engage in low-impact aerobic activities. Cycling on a stationary bike or walking/exercising in a warm pool reduces joint load while improving cardiovascular endurance and muscle strength. Focus on comfortable pace and duration.
exercises.dosage: 20-30 minutes, 3-5 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A person cycling gently on a stationary recumbent bike in a rehabilitation gym, or a person performing gentle leg movements in a warm therapy pool.

exercises.name: Balance and Proprioception Training
exercises.instructions: Perform exercises like single-leg stance (holding onto support initially), tandem stance, or heel-to-toe walking. Gradually progress by reducing support or closing eyes if safe and appropriate.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 15-30 seconds, 3-5 repetitions per leg, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A person standing on one leg next to a stable support (e.g., a chair or parallel bars), maintaining balance.

phase_3.name: Maintenance / Advanced Function Phase - Long-term Management & Prevention
phase_3.goal: To maximize functional independence, promote long-term joint health, prevent progression of deformity, and ensure self-management of symptoms.

exercises.name: Progressive Resistance Training
exercises.instructions: Advance to moderate resistance with weights or resistance bands for major muscle groups. Focus on controlled movements, proper form, and listen to your body to avoid over-exertion or joint stress. Include functional movements like squats, lunges, and step-ups.
exercises.dosage: 8-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per week, with rest days in between.
exercises.image_description: A person performing a bodyweight squat or a lunge with light dumbbells, demonstrating good knee and hip alignment.

exercises.name: Functional Task-Specific Training
exercises.instructions: Practice activities of daily living (ADLs) and instrumental ADLs (IADLs) with an emphasis on joint protection techniques and energy conservation. Examples include practicing lifting techniques, modified gripping for tasks, and organizing environment.
exercises.dosage: Integrate into daily routines with conscious application of techniques.
exercises.image_description: A person demonstrating an ergonomic way to lift an object from the floor, bending at the knees and hips, keeping the back straight, or using adaptive equipment for dressing.

exercises.name: Low-Impact Aerobic and Recreational Activities
exercises.instructions: Continue regular low-impact activities like swimming, walking, cycling, or Tai Chi. Encourage participation in modified recreational activities that respect joint limitations and promote overall well-being.
exercises.dosage: 30-60 minutes, 3-5 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A person practicing Tai Chi outdoors in a park, or enjoying a brisk walk on a level path.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assessment should focus on a thorough joint examination (swelling, tenderness, deformity, limited ROM, crepitus), assessment of functional limitations using validated outcome measures (e.g., HAQ-DI, DAS28), evaluation of pain and fatigue levels, and review of medical history and laboratory findings (e.g., RF, anti-CCP, ESR, CRP). Diagnosis is typically made by a rheumatologist based on clinical criteria and lab tests.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy must be performed with extreme caution. Gentle, non-painful joint mobilizations (Grade I-II oscillations) may be used to reduce pain and maintain joint play, particularly in stable joints not experiencing active inflammation. Soft tissue mobilization for muscle spasm or guarding around joints can be beneficial. Aggressive mobilization, manipulation, or stretching during acute flares is contraindicated due to increased joint laxity, inflammation, and potential for tissue damage.
clinical_notes.precautions: Respect pain during all activities. Avoid over-stressing inflamed joints. Educate patients on joint protection strategies (e.g., using larger joints, distributing force, avoiding prolonged static positions, using assistive devices). Monitor for signs of systemic inflammation (fever, increased fatigue). Be aware of medication side effects (e.g., corticosteroid-induced osteoporosis, skin fragility). Emphasize energy conservation and pacing activities to manage fatigue.

scientific_reference: Smolen JS, Landewé RBM, Bijlsma JWRJ, et al. EULAR recommendations for the management of rheumatoid arthritis with synthetic and biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs: 2022 update. Ann Rheum Dis. 2023;82(1):3-18. American College of Rheumatology (ACR) Guidelines for the Management of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
